items.title: Houthis raid UN offices in Yemen's Sanaa
items.standfirst: Yemen's militant group Houthis raided the offices of several United Nations agencies in the country's capital city of Sanaa and detained at least one UN employee, the Associated Press reported on Sund...
items.content: Yemen's militant group Houthis raided the offices of several United Nations agencies in the country's capital city of Sanaa and detained at least one UN employee, the Associated Press reported on Sund...

items.title: Houthi forces raid UN food and children’s agencies in Yemen’s capital, detain WFP staffer
items.standfirst: The Iran-backed Houthis on Sunday raided offices of the United Nations’ food and children's agencies in Yemen’s capital, detaining at least one U.N. employee, officials said, as the rebels tighten security across Sanaa following the Israeli killing of their prime minister and several Cabinet…
items.content: The Iran-backed Houthis on Sunday raided offices of the United Nations’ food and children's agencies in Yemen’s capital, detaining at least one U.N. employee, officials said, as the rebels tighten security across Sanaa following the Israeli killing of their prime minister and several Cabinet…

items.title: Iran-backed Houthis raid UN food and children's agencies in Yemen, detain employee
items.standfirst: The Iran-backed Houthis on Sunday raided offices of the United Nations' food and children's agencies in Yemen's capital, detaining at least one U.N. employee, officials said.
items.content: The Iran-backed Houthis on Sunday raided offices of the United Nations' food and children's agencies in Yemen's capital, detaining at least one U.N. employee, officials said.(Image credit: Osamah Abdulrahman/AP)

items.title: Houthis detain at least one UN worker in raids on two agencies in Sana’a
items.standfirst: Iran-backed group’s security forces raid offices of World Food Programme and Unicef in Yemen’s capitalThe Iranian-backed Houthis raided offices of the UN’s food, health and children’s agencies in Yemen’s capital, detaining several employees, officials said, as the rebels tightened security across Sana’a after the Israeli killing of their prime minister and several cabinet members.Abeer Etefa, a spokesperson for the World Food Programme (WFP), told the Associated Press that security forces raided the agencies’ offices in the Houthi-controlled capital Sana’a on Sunday morning. She said at least one staff member was detained in the city and others reportedly detained in other areas. Continue reading...
items.content: Iran-backed group’s security forces raid offices of World Food Programme and Unicef in Yemen’s capitalThe Iranian-backed Houthis raided offices of the UN’s food, health and children’s agencies in Yemen’s capital, detaining several employees, officials said, as the rebels tightened security across Sana’a after the Israeli killing of their prime minister and several cabinet members.Abeer Etefa, a spokesperson for the World Food Programme (WFP), told the Associated Press that security forces raided the agencies’ offices in the Houthi-controlled capital Sana’a on Sunday morning. She said at least one staff member was detained in the city and others reportedly detained in other areas. Continue reading...

items.title: Yemen’s Houthis vow vengeance after PM killed by Israel
items.standfirst: Yemen’s Houthis has vowed ‘vengeance’ against Israel after confirming that their prime minister, Ahmed al-Rahawi, was ki
items.content: Yemen’s Houthis has vowed ‘vengeance’ against Israel after confirming that their prime minister, Ahmed al-Rahawi, was ki

items.title: Israeli airstrike kills Houthi prime minister in Yemen, rebels say
items.standfirst: Ahmed al-Rahawi killed alongside several ministers gathered for prerecorded speech by rebel group’s leaderAn Israeli airstrike killed the prime minister of the Houthi rebel-controlled government in Yemen’s capital, Sana’a, the Houthis have said.Ahmed al-Rahawi was killed in a strike in Sana’a on Thursday along with a number of ministers, the rebels said in a statement on Saturday. Other ministers and officials were wounded, the statement added without providing further details. Continue reading...
items.content: Ahmed al-Rahawi killed alongside several ministers gathered for prerecorded speech by rebel group’s leaderAn Israeli airstrike killed the prime minister of the Houthi rebel-controlled government in Yemen’s capital, Sana’a, the Houthis have said.Ahmed al-Rahawi was killed in a strike in Sana’a on Thursday along with a number of ministers, the rebels said in a statement on Saturday. Other ministers and officials were wounded, the statement added without providing further details. Continue reading...

items.title: Houthis confirm their prime minister killed in Israeli strike

items.content: Ahmed Ghaleb Nasser al-Rahawi and several other Houthi officials were killed in the attack, the Iran-backed movement says.

items.content: Israel has killed the Houthi rebel prime minister Ahmed al Rahawi, the Iranian-backed militant group has said.

items.title: Houthi rebels say Israeli airstrike killed their prime minister in Yemen's capital

items.content: The Iranian-backed Houthis said an Israeli airstrike killed the prime minister of the rebel-controlled government in the Yemeni capital, Sanaa.(Image credit: Osamah Abdulrahman)

ai_summary: Houthis raided UN agencies' offices in Sanaa, Yemen's capital, on Sunday morning.
At least one UN employee was detained during the raids by the Houthi forces.
The raids targeted the World Food Programme and UNICEF offices in Sanaa.
The Houthis tightened security in Sanaa following an Israeli killing.
The UN agencies' offices were raided in the Houthi-controlled capital city.

items.title: Widespread protests force Indonesia U-turn
items.standfirst: Indonesia was engulfed by widespread protests driven by economic discontent and opposition to police brutality, marking the greatest challenge yet to President Prabowo Subianto’s government. Demonstrators first took to the streets on Monday to push back against the country’s rising cost of living,…
items.content: Indonesia was engulfed by widespread protests driven by economic discontent and opposition to police brutality, marking the greatest challenge yet to President Prabowo Subianto’s government. Demonstrators first took to the streets on Monday to push back against the country’s rising cost of living,…

items.content: Prabowo Subianto says some parliament policies to be revoked as he also promises stern action against rioters, looters.

items.content: President Prabowo Subianto cancels trip to China amid protests fuelled by economic discontent

items.title: Three dead after protests over death of taxi driver in Indonesia
items.standfirst: The demonstrations - which also focus on cost-of-living and politicians expenses - are seen as a key test for President Prabowo Subianto.
items.content: The demonstrations - which also focus on cost-of-living and politicians expenses - are seen as a key test for President Prabowo Subianto.

ai_summary: Widespread protests in Indonesia were fueled by economic discontent and police brutality.
President Prabowo Subianto announced cuts to lawmakers' perks after the protests.
The President also promised stern action against rioters and looters.
The Indonesian finance minister's home was looted during the unrest.
Three deaths were reported during the protests over a taxi driver's death.

clusters.title: China hosts summit aimed at countering Western-led order
clusters.neutral_headline: China Hosts Summit with Putin, Modi, and Other Leaders

items.title: China hosts summit aimed at countering Western-led order
items.standfirst: China on Sunday welcomed more than a dozen world leaders, including Russia’s Vladimir Putin and India’s Narendra Modi, for a summit aimed at countering a Western-led world order. Modi, who hasn’t visited China since 2018, also met with Chinese leader Xi Jinping — a sign of the cautious…
items.content: China on Sunday welcomed more than a dozen world leaders, including Russia’s Vladimir Putin and India’s Narendra Modi, for a summit aimed at countering a Western-led world order. Modi, who hasn’t visited China since 2018, also met with Chinese leader Xi Jinping — a sign of the cautious…

items.title: Sco Summit: Xi aims at showing global south unity, with Modi and Putin
items.standfirst: China’s Xi Jinping welcomed on Sunday Russia’s Vladimir Putin, India’s Narendra Modi and leaders from around 20 countries to the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit in Tianjin, a high-security gathering aimed at boosting Beijing’s influence and promoting "a multipolar world order". Shirli Sitbon has more.
items.content: China’s Xi Jinping welcomed on Sunday Russia’s Vladimir Putin, India’s Narendra Modi and leaders from around 20 countries to the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit in Tianjin, a high-security gathering aimed at boosting Beijing’s influence and promoting "a multipolar world order". Shirli Sitbon has more.

items.title: SCO Summit: Putin, Modi join Xi in Tianjin amid Trump tariff war
items.standfirst: China’s Xi Jinping welcomed on Sunday Russia’s Vladimir Putin, India’s Narendra Modi and leaders from around 20 countries to the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit in Tianjin, a high-security gathering aimed at boosting Beijing’s influence and promoting "a multipolar world order". France24 correspondent Jan Camenzind Broomby reports from Tapei, Taiwan.
items.content: China’s Xi Jinping welcomed on Sunday Russia’s Vladimir Putin, India’s Narendra Modi and leaders from around 20 countries to the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit in Tianjin, a high-security gathering aimed at boosting Beijing’s influence and promoting "a multipolar world order". France24 correspondent Jan Camenzind Broomby reports from Tapei, Taiwan.

items.title: Putin, Modi and other world leaders in China for summit
items.standfirst: Russian President Vladimir Putin and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi are among the 20 world leaders attending a regional security summit in China.
items.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi are among the 20 world leaders attending a regional security summit in China.

items.title: China and India pledge to be 'partners not rivals'
items.standfirst: Xi Jinping and Narendra Modi met on the sidelines of a summit that Russia's Vladimir Putin is also attending.
items.content: Xi Jinping and Narendra Modi met on the sidelines of a summit that Russia's Vladimir Putin is also attending.

items.title: India and China seek a business reboot
items.standfirst: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi travels to China this weekend for his first visit in seven years, joining Chinese President Xi Jinping and Russian President Vladimir Putin at a regional security summit in Tianjin. The trip comes amid strained relations with Washington, just days after the US doubled tariffs on Indian exports to 50% in response to New Delhi’s continued purchases of Russian oil. FRANCE 24 welcomes the editor-in-chief of the China-Global South Project, Eric Olander, to discuss the rapprochement between India and China.
items.content: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi travels to China this weekend for his first visit in seven years, joining Chinese President Xi Jinping and Russian President Vladimir Putin at a regional security summit in Tianjin. The trip comes amid strained relations with Washington, just days after the US doubled tariffs on Indian exports to 50% in response to New Delhi’s continued purchases of Russian oil. FRANCE 24 welcomes the editor-in-chief of the China-Global South Project, Eric Olander, to discuss the rapprochement between India and China.

items.title: Xi hosts Putin, Modi at SCO summit in show of Global South unity
items.standfirst: China’s Xi Jinping welcomed on Sunday Russia’s Vladimir Putin, India’s Narendra Modi and leaders from around 20 countries to the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit in Tianjin, a high-security gathering aimed at boosting Beijing’s influence and promoting "a multipolar world order". France24 correspondent Jan Camenzind Broomby reports from Tapei, Taiwan.
items.content: China’s Xi Jinping welcomed on Sunday Russia’s Vladimir Putin, India’s Narendra Modi and leaders from around 20 countries to the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation summit in Tianjin, a high-security gathering aimed at boosting Beijing’s influence and promoting "a multipolar world order". France24 correspondent Jan Camenzind Broomby reports from Tapei, Taiwan.

ai_summary: China hosted a summit with leaders including Putin and Modi.
The summit aimed to counter a Western-led world order.
Modi met with Xi Jinping on the sidelines of the summit.
The summit was held in Tianjin, China, a high-security gathering.
India and China are seeking to reboot business relations.

items.title: Israeli military says it killed Hamas spokesperson amid expanding offensive in Gaza
items.standfirst: Israeli Defense Minister Israel Katz identified the spokesperson as Abu Obeida, the nom de guerre for the official who represented Hamas’ Qassam Brigades. He was killed over the weekend. Hamas has not commented on the claim.
items.content: Israeli Defense Minister Israel Katz identified the spokesperson as Abu Obeida, the nom de guerre for the official who represented Hamas’ Qassam Brigades. He was killed over the weekend. Hamas has not commented on the claim.

items.title: 8/31: Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan
items.standfirst: This week on "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan," Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem discusses the federal government's deployment to U.S. cities, while Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker discusses the administration's plans for Chicago. Plus, World Food Programme executive director Cindy McCain discusses the situation in Gaza.
items.content: This week on "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan," Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem discusses the federal government's deployment to U.S. cities, while Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker discusses the administration's plans for Chicago. Plus, World Food Programme executive director Cindy McCain discusses the situation in Gaza.

items.title: Chicago Mayor Johnson defies Trump’s federal immigration enforcement plan for the city
items.standfirst: The Chicago Police Department will be barred from helping federal authorities with civil immigration enforcement or any related patrols, traffic stops and checkpoints during the surge, according to an executive order signed by the city's mayor.
items.content: The Chicago Police Department will be barred from helping federal authorities with civil immigration enforcement or any related patrols, traffic stops and checkpoints during the surge, according to an executive order signed by the city's mayor.

items.title: Noem: "Haven't taken anything off the table" on immigration operations in cities
items.standfirst: Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem said that there's been "ongoing operations with ICE in Chicago and throughout Illinois and other states," adding that "we do intend to add more resources to those operations."
items.content: Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem said that there's been "ongoing operations with ICE in Chicago and throughout Illinois and other states," adding that "we do intend to add more resources to those operations."

items.title: Cindy McCain shares firsthand account of famine in Gaza: "It's truly a devastating situation"
items.standfirst: World Food Programme executive director Cindy McCain recently visited Gaza, where she said she witnessed the food crisis firsthand. McCain told "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" that she met with a family of 11 who shared photos of themselves from before the conflict with Israel, and she "didn't even recognize these people."
items.content: World Food Programme executive director Cindy McCain recently visited Gaza, where she said she witnessed the food crisis firsthand. McCain told "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" that she met with a family of 11 who shared photos of themselves from before the conflict with Israel, and she "didn't even recognize these people."

JB Pritzker told "Face the Nation with Margaret Brennan" that he thinks the military deployments to American cities are an "invasion with U.S. troops."

clusters.title: Two million impacted as Pakistan’s Punjab faces worst floods in its history
clusters.neutral_headline: Pakistan's Punjab Province Faces Severe Flooding

items.title: Two million impacted as Pakistan’s Punjab faces worst floods in its history
items.standfirst: While South Asia's seasonal monsoon brings rainfall that farmers depend on, climate change is making it deadly.
items.content: While South Asia's seasonal monsoon brings rainfall that farmers depend on, climate change is making it deadly.

items.title: Rising floodwaters in Pakistan’s Punjab province put 2 million people at risk
items.standfirst: Pakistan’s eastern Punjab province is dealing with the biggest flood in its history, a senior official said Sunday, as water levels of rivers rise to all-time highs.
items.content: Pakistan’s eastern Punjab province is dealing with the biggest flood in its history, a senior official said Sunday, as water levels of rivers rise to all-time highs.

items.title: Pakistan’s Punjab province faces worst floods in its history
items.standfirst: More than two million people have been affected by flooding in Pakistan’s worst-hit province of Punjab.
items.content: More than two million people have been affected by flooding in Pakistan’s worst-hit province of Punjab.

items.title: Pakistan’s Punjab evacuates half a million people stranded by floods
items.standfirst: Floods in Punjab displace nearly 500,000 people and kill dozens amid the largest rescue in eastern province's history.
items.content: Floods in Punjab displace nearly 500,000 people and kill dozens amid the largest rescue in eastern province's history.

items.title: Pakistan evacuates half a million people as latest floods kill 30
items.standfirst: Nearly half a million people have been displaced in eastern Pakistan after days of torrential rain caused rivers to overflow, rescue officials said, as large-scale operations continue amid a devastating monsoon season. The Punjab Disaster Management Authority (PDMA) reported Saturday that since June 26, the monsoon has claimed 835 lives nationwide, including 195 in Punjab province. Shirli Sitbon reports.
items.content: Nearly half a million people have been displaced in eastern Pakistan after days of torrential rain caused rivers to overflow, rescue officials said, as large-scale operations continue amid a devastating monsoon season. The Punjab Disaster Management Authority (PDMA) reported Saturday that since June 26, the monsoon has claimed 835 lives nationwide, including 195 in Punjab province. Shirli Sitbon reports.

ai_summary: Pakistan's Punjab province is experiencing its worst floods in history.
Over two million people are at risk due to rising floodwaters.
Nearly 500,000 people have been displaced by the floods.
Dozens of people have died due to the flooding in Punjab.
The monsoon season has claimed 835 lives nationwide.

items.title: Norway signs £10bn deal for anti-submarine warships built in UK
items.standfirst: MoD says agreement will support 4,000 jobs and ‘significantly strengthen Nato’s northern flank’ Norway has agreed a £10bn deal that will see anti-submarine warships built in the UK, as the two countries plan joint operations in northern Europe to deal with increased Russian activity. The Ministry…
items.content: MoD says agreement will support 4,000 jobs and ‘significantly strengthen Nato’s northern flank’ Norway has agreed a £10bn deal that will see anti-submarine warships built in the UK, as the two countries plan joint operations in northern Europe to deal with increased Russian activity. The Ministry…

items.title: Norway signs £10bn deal for anti-submarine warships built in UK
items.standfirst: MoD says agreement will support 4,000 jobs and ‘significantly strengthen Nato’s northern flank’Norway has agreed a £10bn deal for anti-submarine warships that will be built in the UK, as the two countries plan joint operations in northern Europe to deal with increased Russian activity.The Ministry of Defence (MoD) said the agreement to build Type 26 frigates was the UK’s biggest ever warship export deal by value, and Norway’s biggest defence procurement deal. Continue reading...
items.content: MoD says agreement will support 4,000 jobs and ‘significantly strengthen Nato’s northern flank’Norway has agreed a £10bn deal for anti-submarine warships that will be built in the UK, as the two countries plan joint operations in northern Europe to deal with increased Russian activity.The Ministry of Defence (MoD) said the agreement to build Type 26 frigates was the UK’s biggest ever warship export deal by value, and Norway’s biggest defence procurement deal. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Norway signed a £10 billion deal for anti-submarine warships built in the UK.
The deal will support 4,000 jobs, according to the MoD.
The agreement is the UK's biggest warship export deal by value.
The warships will be Type 26 frigates.
The deal aims to strengthen NATO's northern flank.

clusters.title: Former CDC official ‘only sees harm’ to public health under RFK Jr’s leadership
clusters.neutral_headline: Former CDC Official Expresses Concerns About RFK Jr

items.title: Former CDC official ‘only sees harm’ to public health under RFK Jr’s leadership
items.standfirst: Demetre Daskalakis, who resigned after White House fired CDC chief, cautions against ‘undoing of vaccination’ to ABCThe former immunizations director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has warned of the future of American health under the leadership of Donald Trump’s health secretary, Robert F Kennedy Jr.In an interview on Sunday with ABC, Demetre Daskalakis – who resigned this week in protest over the White House’s firing of CDC director Susan Monarez – said: “From my vantage point as a doctor who’s taken the Hippocratic Oath, I only see harm coming.” Continue reading...
items.content: Demetre Daskalakis, who resigned after White House fired CDC chief, cautions against ‘undoing of vaccination’ to ABCThe former immunizations director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has warned of the future of American health under the leadership of Donald Trump’s health secretary, Robert F Kennedy Jr.In an interview on Sunday with ABC, Demetre Daskalakis – who resigned this week in protest over the White House’s firing of CDC director Susan Monarez – said: “From my vantage point as a doctor who’s taken the Hippocratic Oath, I only see harm coming.” Continue reading...

ai_summary: A former CDC official warns of potential harm under RFK Jr.'s leadership.

The White House is defending Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
The CDC has seen departures of top officials recently.

clusters.title: First the great migration, now the big hold: why workers are staying put
clusters.neutral_headline: Workers staying put, reversing "great migration" trend

items.title: First the great migration, now the big hold: why workers are staying put
items.standfirst: A Robert Half survey finds 73% of workers plan to stay put through 2025, citing culture, pay and a weak job market The tide has turned. The great migration – when the shift to remote work prompted people to quit their jobs in droves – is officially over. Now comes the big hold. According to a new…
items.content: A Robert Half survey finds 73% of workers plan to stay put through 2025, citing culture, pay and a weak job market The tide has turned. The great migration – when the shift to remote work prompted people to quit their jobs in droves – is officially over. Now comes the big hold. According to a new…

items.title: First the great migration, now the big hold: why workers are staying put
items.standfirst: A Robert Half survey finds 73% of workers plan to stay put through 2025, citing culture, pay and a weak job marketThe tide has turned. The great migration – when the shift to remote work prompted people to quit their jobs in droves – is officially over. Now comes the big hold.According to a new survey from consulting firm Robert Half, 73% of respondents – workers at companies – said they plan to stay in their current roles through 2025. They gave reasons like having “positive company culture” and “feeling professionally fulfilled” or “being well compensated” at their current job. But there’s also a fourth reason why so many are staying put: the job market isn’t great and people are worried. Continue reading...
items.content: A Robert Half survey finds 73% of workers plan to stay put through 2025, citing culture, pay and a weak job marketThe tide has turned. The great migration – when the shift to remote work prompted people to quit their jobs in droves – is officially over. Now comes the big hold.According to a new survey from consulting firm Robert Half, 73% of respondents – workers at companies – said they plan to stay in their current roles through 2025. They gave reasons like having “positive company culture” and “feeling professionally fulfilled” or “being well compensated” at their current job. But there’s also a fourth reason why so many are staying put: the job market isn’t great and people are worried. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A Robert Half survey indicates 73% of workers plan to stay in current roles.
Workers cite company culture, pay, and a weak job market as reasons.
The "great migration" of workers quitting jobs is officially over.
The survey included responses from workers at various companies.
Many workers feel professionally fulfilled in their current positions.

clusters.title: Leading Ukrainian 'statesman' and Maidan protest leader assassinated in Ukraine
clusters.neutral_headline: Leading Ukrainian 'statesman' and Maidan protest leader assassinated in Ukraine

items.title: Leading Ukrainian 'statesman' and Maidan protest leader assassinated in Ukraine
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned the “horrific murder” of Andriy Parubiy, a leading figure in Ukraine’s 2014 pro-European "Maidan" protest movement, who was shot and killed in Lviv on Saturday. A former speaker of parliament, Parubiy, 54, also previously served as secretary of the National Security and Defence Council. Caroline Baum reports.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned the “horrific murder” of Andriy Parubiy, a leading figure in Ukraine’s 2014 pro-European "Maidan" protest movement, who was shot and killed in Lviv on Saturday. A former speaker of parliament, Parubiy, 54, also previously served as secretary of the National Security and Defence Council. Caroline Baum reports.

items.title: Investigation launched into ‘horrific murder’ of Ukrainian politician in Lviv
items.standfirst: Former parliamentary speaker Andriy Parubiy shot dead as EU ministers meet to discuss measures to force Moscow to the negotiating tableA Ukrainian former parliamentary speaker was shot dead in Lviv on Saturday, authorities said, as European foreign ministers met to discuss increasing pressure on Moscow to end its war against Ukraine.Andriy Parubiy, a member of parliament who served as parliamentary speaker from 2016 to 2019 and a key figure in Ukraine’s 2013 pro-European Maidan revolution, was shot dead, prosecutors said. A murder investigation has been launched and the president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, condemned the killing as a “horrific murder”. Continue reading...
items.content: Former parliamentary speaker Andriy Parubiy shot dead as EU ministers meet to discuss measures to force Moscow to the negotiating tableA Ukrainian former parliamentary speaker was shot dead in Lviv on Saturday, authorities said, as European foreign ministers met to discuss increasing pressure on Moscow to end its war against Ukraine.Andriy Parubiy, a member of parliament who served as parliamentary speaker from 2016 to 2019 and a key figure in Ukraine’s 2013 pro-European Maidan revolution, was shot dead, prosecutors said. A murder investigation has been launched and the president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, condemned the killing as a “horrific murder”. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Andriy Parubiy, a key figure in the Maidan revolution, was shot dead in Lviv.
President Zelenskyy condemned the killing as a "horrific murder."
Parubiy was a former speaker of parliament.
The murder investigation has been launched by authorities.
EU ministers met to discuss measures against Moscow.
